div1.p: Houston provides family news. She discusses letters of congratulation for the passage of the pension bill.

div1.head: Letter from Martha P. Houston to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 24, 1902
div1.p:
I am inclined
to begin this letter to you with an apology
as I did not write my usual Sunday
letter. I went to church in the morning
and in the afternoon Fred and family
come in and in the evening I seem to
have no energy to do anything-

As I write. Mabel has gone to see a
friend who is ill - and the children
are supposed to have their nap now.
but I hear them talking - You would
be amused at Peggy. she always
wakes up once during the night-
When Mabel went into babys room
the other night as she was crying
and said what is the matter? Peggy
said crying botta - telling she was
crying for it her bottle -

I never know how to spell the baby
talk - so must in her explain -

If I go to her anytime during the night
she always says tory. tory, asking me
to tell her a story. Houston sends his
love, and says tell gammy about
the balloon man - and that he had
a balloon the uder day “-- He says
tomorrow we might go to see Baltimore
gammy ”

Did I write you Jennie has been
confirmed at the little church near
them? I think I did --

Miss Helen Hyde expects to visit
Jennie in May- I received a letter
from Sister Helen - (Nell) to day she
was looking forward to seeing you
very soon! Spent evening & went to a
lecture by Voorlanger, on Napoleon
the services are interesting, and the
prayers are beautiful - We enjoyed the
lecture very much. We still have
the same cook (Hannah) since Emma
went away- She concluded to remain
she seems to be reliable - and not
at all inclined to go out, especially at
night. which is some comfort to
Mabel & myself. her kitchen is so very
(3)
clean it does one good to see it by
way of contrast to Emmas' --

she is a very good cook. at present
Flora whom you know- comes every
day to look after the children- she
gets along very nicely with them
and they play in the back garden
till noon every day-

I have just read one of the cutest
and most amusing books
“The Bread line”, by Biglow Payne
I wish you would try to get it.
It is so very funny and one could
read it in two evenings -

Some little time ago Mabel received
a letter of congratulation from
Dr Gilman, in which he enclosed a
number of letters he had received
in regard to Jesse - work, also a
newspaper clipping, he thought Mabel
would wish to keep them for the
children. She also received a note
of congratulation from Senator McCormas
he thought the amount disgraceful--
however --

March is such a cold month
here that we will be glad to see
the end of it - They hope to remove
the building deficit. Easter Sunday-
the amount is seven thousand
dollars, three (3) thousand of which
is pledged by the Vestry if the
rest is given-

last Sunday fifteen fifty three were
confirmed last Sunday!

Please give my love to Mrs Seth
with love and best wishes to your
own dear self-
